Ethan Edwards.Action: Rides alone across harsh terrain, visibly hardened and experienced, with well-worn and patched clothing and equipment, indicating survival skills and resourcefulness.
Greets Aaron and Martha with a stiff, constrained manner; a sign of emotional reservation despite underlying affection.
Acknowledges children by name and responds to their presence without hostility, though somewhat awkwardly.
Displays impatience or sharpness toward Martin when he takes the horse's bridle without asking.
Displays confident body language by dismounting his horse slowly and stiffly, maintains a steady gaze on Martha, showing composure and emotional control.
Responds to Aaron's inquiries with curt, dismissive remarks, indicating control over the conversation and unwillingness to be manipulated.
Recognizes and calls Ben by name, shows attentiveness to children despite not being used to them.
Commands Martin abruptly to 'MOMENTO!' causing Martin to halt unexpectedly, demonstrating assertiveness and control over his surroundings.
Mistakes Martin for a half-breed, expresses blunt indifference about rescuing him, does not trust Martin to handle his horse.
Accepts Martha's offer to take his coat and acknowledges her welcome home without warmth.
Takes back his pack from Martin, not trusting him to hold it, showing a protective and confident handling of his belongings.
Bluntly downplays his role in finding Martin without embellishment, showing straightforward and practical communication.
Misidentifies Martin initially as a half-breed, reflecting a quick but somewhat inaccurate judgment.
Does not explain or justify his distrust of Martin, choosing instead to act on his own judgment without concern for others' opinions.
Ethan straightens contentedly after shaving and changing shirt, acknowledges Martin's good night despite dislike of 'Uncle' title.
Answers Ben's curious questions about the saber matter-of-factly without warmth or hostility.
Manages dinner proceedings with quiet authority, appears confident and content after shaving and changing, commands attention at the table.
Responds matter-of-factly to Ben’s questions about his saber and war kills, indicating experience and control.
Dislikes familiarity implied by being called 'Uncle' but still courteously acknowledges it; shows controlled emotional intelligence.
Does not intervene in minor household disputes or disputes over tasks (Debbie helping with dishes) showing possible omission of leadership at home.
Gives Debbie a gold medallion he picked up in Mexico, allowing her to keep it despite concerns about her age.
Looks gravely at Debbie and turns away from Martha and Aaron without further explanation.
Remembers the gold medal and produces it promptly to replace Lucy's worn locket, demonstrating thoughtfulness and preparedness.
Offers the medal without providing much explanation or engaging further when questioned by Martha and Aaron, possibly indicating a reserved or not fully communicative nature.
Refuses to explain himself to Martha and Aaron, turns away and looks into the fire.
Under pressure from Aaron, almost welcomes the challenge but responds hard, showing defensiveness.
Declares intent to pay his own way and contributes significant money to the household without pride or boast.
Responds to a challenge about why he stayed beyond all need by confronting it directly and confidently.
Demonstrates financial preparedness and resourcefulness by carrying and revealing substantial wealth in gold coins and a money belt.
Is unable to provide a verbal answer when questioned about his prolonged stay after the war, indicating possible emotional or strategic withholding.
Notices Martha's injured hand and gently takes it, asking softly about the cut, revealing concern.
Displays bitterness and brooding expression after Martha and Aaron enter the bedroom, showing emotional distance and possible bitterness.
Carefully observes the condition of the gold coins and responds nonchalantly when questioned, showing calm awareness.
Notices Martha's injured hand and gently inquires about it, showing attentiveness and emotional intelligence.
Exhibits bitterness and brooding when left alone, appearing emotionally burdened but still controlled.
Calmly appropriates Clayton's coffee cup, mocking his new title, shows disregard for formalities and others' feelings
Does not answer Clayton's question about his absence, maintaining a cold distance
Enters unnoticed and confidently appropriates the coffee cup, displaying calmness and mockery toward authority.
Avoids directly answering Clayton's question about his absence at the surrender, showing evasiveness.
Insists on going along to help despite being told not to, showing protectiveness and commitment.
Sloshes the dregs of his coffee into the fire, spattering Mose, demonstrating a brusque and somewhat disrespectful behavior.
Questions authority and legal formalities with a sarcastic tone, implying a tough and untrusting nature.
Looks briefly and meaningfully at Martha, indicating a moment of human connection beneath his stern exterior.
Addresses Clayton levelly but with a pointed reminder about oaths, showing directness and expectation of honesty.
Tells Aaron to stick close, indicating protective concern.
Looks at Martha and Aaron thoughtfully before leaving, suggesting some attentiveness or care.
Addresses Clayton and others with calm, level speech showing confidence and a clear sense of priorities.
Gives a practical instruction to Aaron to stick close, showing protective and tactical awareness.
Strides out determinedly towards the task ahead, demonstrating decisiveness and leadership.
Salutes Martha with a gloved hand, a formal and respectful gesture.
Reacts negatively and grudgingly to Martin's use of 'Uncle,' shows irritation and emotional distance.
Rejects formal titles but responds jokingly to Martin, showing a subtle friendly side.
Leads the posse at a steady, careful pace, studying the terrain and trail closely alongside Mose.
Corrects Martin firmly yet without losing composure, showing confidence and control in interpersonal interactions.
Fires revolver into the air to stop reckless pursuit, trying to control the situation and protect the group.
Inspects slaughtered cattle and shows anger over the senseless violence, indicating concern and moral outrage.
Makes harsh accusatory statement about the raiding tribe, showing intolerance toward the perpetrators.
Insists on pacing the journey cautiously and allowing horses to rest and be fed, despite pressure to hurry.
Gives Mose an angry look after Mose expresses preference for other tribes, showing intolerance.
Ruthlessly discards unnecessary equipment to prepare for travel.
Insists on a methodical, calm approach by feeding horses and resting before riding forty miles, rather than rushing immediately despite others' impatience.
Ruthlessly discards unnecessary equipment from his saddle to travel efficiently, demonstrating practical preparation and prioritization.
Shrugs off others' impatience and maintains his chosen plan without being swayed by emotion.
Ethan's cavalry sabre is kept by Ben carefully, indicating respect for his skills and capability.
Is seen with his sabre confidently in hand while others react to incoming information, suggesting a readiness to act if needed.
Rides with Mose at a slower, more controlled pace, not rushing like others.

No direct action or statement by Ethan in this excerpt; passive observer or non-participant in critical moments.
Rides toward Martin and Mose but nearly rides Martin down, shouting 'Out of my way!'
Rides with determination toward the ranch despite urgent calls and obstacles, shows single-minded focus.
Fails to notice Martin calling out and nearly rides him down, showing lack of situational awareness and consideration.
Stops at the porch, takes off his hat, shows visible sorrow and slumps with grief upon seeing the damage.
Calls out for Lucy and Deborah inside the house, showing concern and care.
Forbids Martin from entering the house harshly and then knocks him out with a brutal but merciful blow to prevent further harm.
Looks compassionately at Martin after knocking him out.
Runs to the hilltop, calling for Lucy, showing urgent worry and hope.
Stoops fearfully to investigate what seems to be a concealed body, showing vulnerability and concern.
Shows no visible emotional reaction at the gravesite or during the prayer, standing dry-eyed and responding harshly to the minister's reading.
Turns impatient and stone-faced when Mrs. Jorgensen appeals emotionally; shrugs off her plea to avoid vengeance and ignores her request.
Expresses impatience and harshness toward Martin, who is grieving and vulnerable.
Listens impatiently but acknowledges the importance of the mission; mounts and rides out decisively despite emotional appeals.
Shrugs off Mrs. Jorgensen's emotional plea and ignores potential diplomatic or emotional considerations.
Face a study of relentless purpose as the men ride in search
Offers Nesby an opportunity to back out of the pursuit, showing consideration for others' feelings and limits.
Takes a grim, culturally symbolic action by mutilating the dead Comanche to deny them spiritual peace, an act showing ruthlessness and a lack of empathy.
Confronts Brad's hesitation by demanding he finish the grim task, expressing impatience and severity.
Takes decisive action to scalp the dead Comanche, understanding the cultural and psychological impact of the act on their enemy.
Confidently explains his motives and the significance behind his actions, showing knowledgeable insight into Comanche beliefs.
Offers support to Nesby, indicating leadership and awareness of group morale.
Engages in a grisly task deliberately and with grim determination, maintaining control and focus.
Takes a defiant and aggressive stance insisting on attacking the Comanches directly despite others' concerns.
Dismisses Clayton’s plan and others’ opinions harshly, including a derogatory comment about Martin being a quarter-breed Cherokee.
Ultimately complies with an order from Captain Clayton but with a pointed, resentful comment.
Challenges Clayton’s plan based on his own knowledge of Comanche habits, demonstrating confidence and specialized understanding.
Acknowledges Clayton's authority but delivers a pointed warning about the risk of Clayton being wrong, showing critical thinking and assertiveness.
Acknowledges the presence of potential danger and communicates clearly to the group, showing awareness and leadership.
Grins wryly at Mose's sociable owl hooting, displaying a subtle appreciation for camaraderie despite tension.
Recognizes the significance of the campfire ashes quickly and alerts the group to the danger.
Confidently inquires if there are further orders, ready to follow through calmly.
Shows situational awareness by assessing the environment and maintaining vigilance during the cautious advance.
Observes the tactical situation and comments insightfully that the Comanches have succeeded in surrounding them.
Calmly prepares rifles and cartridges while under potential threat, maintaining composure and readiness.
Groups with others behind cover showing cooperative tactical behavior with comrades.
No direct interaction showing friendliness or overt warmth toward others in this excerpt.
Protects the defense line by shooting at advancing Comanches to help comrades.
Insists on shooting a fleeing enemy despite being stopped by a comrade.
Shows grim determination to find Deborah and Lucy if they are still alive.
Provides a realistic, somewhat harsh view of endurance and survival regarding pursuit of the Comanche.
Watches Martin drink from his canteen and reacts angrily to his thirstiness, showing a sharp reprimand.
Insists that Debbie and Lucy are with the group if still alive, expressing determination and concern.
Dismisses Martin’s suggestion to signal with shots or bonfires, indicating a preference for subtlety and caution.
Rides off alone toward a difficult path showing willingness to face danger by himself.
Looks blankly and gives vague, unnecessary remarks when approached by Martin and Brad, showing signs of confusion or distraction.
Dismisses the loss of his serape casually and refuses to go back to look for it, indicating a possible lack of attention to important details or carelessness.
Maintains gruff demeanor despite confusion, mounts horse, and leads on, showing some physical capability and confidence in continuing the pursuit.
Keeps the truth about Lucy's fate to himself as long as possible to protect others, shows deep grief but tries to shield Brad and Martin from immediate pain.
Responds with anger and fury when Brad questions him about Lucy's death, shutting down communication and expressing frustration harshly.
Correctly identifies that Brad's sighting was a disguised figure and reveals he has already found Lucy's body and buried her, showing clear situational awareness and decisiveness.
Keeps the truth about Lucy's death from Brad and Martin until deemed necessary to reveal it, demonstrating strategic withholding of information to possibly manage emotions or the situation.
Shows emotional restraint outwardly but also unleashes fury when pressured for more details, indicating some difficulty in controlling emotional responses under stress.
Hears Brad's desperate and tragic death but does not react with visible grief or anger; simply listens, then comments 'Let's just hope he took some with him...' and turns away to leave.
Hears Brad's yell and gunfire at the Comanche camp but decides there is nothing they can do and chooses to withdraw peacefully.
Turns his horse and decides to get sleep after the obvious loss of Brad, showing calm judgment under pressure.
Does not attempt a rash rescue or charge into the hostile Comanche camp despite emotional stakes.
Continuing the search relentlessly despite hardship and fatigue, expressing hope that the captive girl is safe even if raised by the enemy.
Rides away slowly and reluctantly, seemingly withdrawn and resigned, showing no overt empathy or interaction with Martin beyond determination.
Persistently follows a difficult and lengthy trail across harsh terrain despite exhaustion and bleak prospects.
Rejects the suggestion to give up after clear signs of hardship and despair, demonstrating confidence and determination.
Slowly turning his mount after prolonged pursuit, indicating a possible moment of doubt or reassessment.
Expresses determination and assurance they will find the missing person despite uncertainty.

Explains with confident certainty that they will find the captors, demonstrating understanding of tracking and persistence.

Continues talking openly about the search and the difficulties encountered despite the grief in the room.
Carefully studies and opens the letter addressed to Mrs. Jorgensen, showing respect and sensitivity.
Shows habitual difficulty with reading, indicating humility or lack of pretension rather than boastfulness.

Having ridden out ahead an hour ago to find Debbie, showing decisiveness and initiative.
